questions.question: Who primarily uses our tax money?

choices.answer: Your employer
The state government
The Federal government
Local businesses

questions.question: Our tax money is spent on all of the following EXCEPT:

choices.answer: Social Security
The Military
Private School Education
National Parks

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a category in the Federal government's spending?

choices.answer: Mandatory spending
Discretionary spending
Interest on loans issued
Interest on national debt

questions.question: What types of taxes contribute to Federal tax revenue?

choices.answer: Corporate Income Tax
Income Tax
Estate Tax
Excise Tax

questions.question: The W-4 form lets...

choices.answer: the government know how much you paid in taxes last year
your employer know how much to withhold from your paycheck
the 3 major credit bureaus know how many dependents you have
you know how much you paid in taxes last year

questions.question: Jess is 21, in college, & has a job that provides 65% of her support. Is she a dependent?

choices.answer: Yes
No

questions.question: What item would you DEFINITELY see on a paystub?

choices.answer: Retirement
Healthcare
Gross Pay
Your occupation/role

questions.question: By claiming "exempt" on the W-4 form...

choices.answer: You are paying all income taxes upfront at the START of the year.
You are saying that you do NOT meet the minimum income requirements to file
You will NOT have income taxes withheld from your paycheck.
You are paying all income taxes at the END of the calendar year.

questions.question: Jason filed his tax return and owes money. If he doesn't want to pay a fee, when should he pay this amount by?

choices.answer: April 15th
October 15th
December 31st
January 1st of the next year

questions.question: True or False: All wages, tips, and bonuses are taxable unless specifically excluded.

choices.answer: True
False

questions.question: Which of the following is FALSE about the W-2 form?

choices.answer: You get 1 W-2 form every year, even if you had multiple jobs
The W-2 is sent out in April of every year
It lets you know how much you earned last year
It lets you know how much was withheld from your paychecks

questions.question: Jason is 15 and earned $1450 at his job last summer. Should he file a tax return?

choices.answer: No, because he didn't earn enough.
No, because you have to be 16 and older to file taxes.
Yes, because he may get a refund.
Yes. You must file taxes even if you didn't earn enough.

questions.question: What do you need to file your 1040 form?

choices.answer: Your W-2
Your W-4
Your prior year's tax return
Social Security Number

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a way you can file your taxes?

choices.answer: Through a tax professional
Mailing in a paper tax return to the Federal government
Using tax software like TurboTax
Through your employer's HR department

questions.question: True or False: A teen's earned income can be reported on a parent's tax return.

choices.answer: True
False

questions.question: If a teen files a tax return, can the parent still claim him/her as a dependent?

choices.answer: Yes. All teens are dependents until they are 18 years old
No. If a teen files a tax return, he/she cannot be claimed
Yes, as long as the teen meets the dependency requirements
Yes, but the parent has to add the teen's income to theirs

questions.question: Luisa earned $1,200 at her part-time job, and $500 from babysitting in cash. Which is TRUE?

choices.answer: She will report her total income as $1,700.
She will report her total income as $1,200.
She will report her total income as $500.
Luisa is required to file a tax return.

questions.question: Which is TRUE about earned income and unearned income?

choices.answer: Earned is how much you make from a job
Earned is any money you make in interest, dividends, etc.
Unearned is any money you make in interest, dividends, etc.
Unearned is how much you make from a job

questions.question: If you owe taxes, which of the following is FALSE?

choices.answer: You can make a payment using cash
You can delay your payment deadline
With an agreement, you can pay it in installments
You can make a payment with a debit, but not credit card

questions.question: Which is TRUE if you do not pay your taxes?

choices.answer: You owe twice as much the following year
You're more likely to be approved for low interst loans
You cannot go to jail (but you will be heavily fined)
Your credit score may be impacted
